contentrichtext.text: '''Fernando Mezzasoma''' (August 3, 1907 – April 28, 1945) was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[Fascism|fascist]] journalist and political figure. ==Biography== Mezzasoma was born in [[Rome]], the son of middle-class [[Perugia]]ns; from his late teens he showed himself to be a passionate supporter of [[Benito Mussolini]]. Mezzasoma had to contribute to his impovershed family's income from early on, and took several jobs before finishing studies in [[accounting]]. A secretary to the lawyer [[Amedeo Fani]], he was integrated to the state [[bureaucracy]] in 1929, after Fani became undersecretary to the ministry of [[Dino Grandi]] (the [[Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs|Minister of Foreign Affairs]]). In 1931, he joined the ranks of the [[National Fascist Party]] (PNF), and soon after became secretary of the Perugia branch of the [[Gruppo Universitario Fascista]] (GUF), the Fascist [[student organization]]. The following year, Mezzasoma was appointed one of the local PNF leaders in Perugia (holding the position until 1935). He began writing for official magazines, such as ''Dottrina Fascista'' and ''Roma Fascista'', usually under the [[pen name]] ''[[Diogenes of Sinope|Diogene]]''. Editor of ''[[Assalto]]'' in 1934, he became co-editor of the GUF mouthpiece ''[[Libro e Moschetto]]''; in 1937, he published ''Essenza dei GUF'' ("Essence of the GUF"), a [[propaganda]] volume that was distributed throughout the network of Fascist [[youth organization]]s. A national deputy-secretary of the GUF in 1935, he was included to the leadership group of the PNF in January 1937, and its deputy-secretary on February 23, 1939. When Italy entered [[World War II]] as an [[Axis Powers|Axis Power]], he volunteered for the 7th Artillery Division. In 1942, he quit the army to become the director of the Italian press; he continued in that role until 1943. Unlike a great many leading figures of the government (such as [[Galeazzo Ciano]] and [[Dino Grandi]]), he stayed loyal to Mussolini long after the July 1943 [[Grand Council of Fascism]] crisis which ended the latter's rule in [[Rome]]. With the foundation of the [[Nazi Germany]]-assisted [[Italian Social Republic]], he was appointed Mussolini's Minister of Popular Culture, and held this post until the Republic collapsed less than two years later. He clashed with [[Junio Valerio Borghese]] and, on April 19, 1945, left for [[Milano]] - parting with his collaborators (including [[Giorgio Almirante]]). It seems that he had the opportunity to flee the region following Germany's defeat, but would have refused, saying: "''I am a minister of Mussolini, I shall die with him''".{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} He was shot by the [[Italian resistance movement|partisans]] in [[Dongo, Italy|Dongo]], captured while he was trying to make his way to [[Switzerland]]. ==External links== *[http://web.archive.org/web/20091029025754/http://geocities.com/~orion47/ITALY/Italy-Govt.html Short bios of Fascist leaders] {{Authority control|VIAF=64772795}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Mezzasoma, Fernando | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = August 3, 1907 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = April 28, 1945 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mezzasoma, Fernando}} [[Category:1907 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:Writers from Rome]] [[Category:Italian fascists]] [[Category:People of the Italian Social Republic]] [[Category:Italian journalists]] [[Category:Italian people of World War II]] [[Category:Propagandists]] [[Category:Executed politicians]] [[Category:People executed by Italy by firing squad]] [[Category:Italian people executed by firing squad]] [[Category:20th-century executions by Italy]]
